description.narrative: Hiil hooyo is a multi-actor joint project addressing maternal healthcare in Somaliland and Puntland. The key development problem is high maternal mortality having multiple negative effects. Maternal mortality rate in the project areas is one of the highest in the world. The project seeks to enhance women's right and the right of persons with disabilities to maternal healthcare. The project started in 2017 with a pilot phase and the new phase aims to make the results sustainable.The main outcomes are:1. Skil ls and motivation of healthcare workers improved2. Number of mothers and children attending MCHs increased3. Attendance and accessibility of persons with disabilities to MCHs increased4. Partner universities able to conduct independently e-learning program in maternal healthcare and students benefitted from the developed materialThe main outputs and activities include:- 240 healthcare workers passed in-service training on maternal healthcare; 4 trainings- 10 000 persons reached by awareness raising programs ; village meetings school classes media campaigns home visits fathers? clubs- 460 persons trained on the rights of persons with disabilities; training of trainers workshops- 120 university students passed e-learning program in maternal healthcare teachers trained and partner universities networking; e-course for students on-line training for teachers joint meetingsThe project is implemented in 10 districts in 3 areas. For the implementation the FSN has 6 NGO partners of which 3 its member organizations in F inland and 5 university partners of which 2 (Diak and Xamk) in Finland. In addition the Disability Partnership Finland (DPF) offers expertize for disability issues. The innovative cooperative model enforces the civil society and enhances stability.The bene ficiaries of the project include healthcare workers pregnant and breastfeeding mothers with their families persons with disabilities university lecturers and students students in secondary schools the NGO partners and indirectly communities in general in t he project areas with an estimated population of 15 million.
